results.title: K.C.I.: beyond the three r's
results.creator_credit: Scott Barrie, Arthur Ham, Silva Basmajian and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Kitchener Waterloo Collegiate and Vocational School embodies some of the best features of public secondary education today. The school encourages students to learn beyond the classroom through innovative programs like Cooperative Education or Community Involvement, and welcomes adults into the school to complete their education or upgrade their skills. Through candid views of school activities, classroom discussions, and interviews with staff and students, the film takes its audience through a busy day at a large urban high school. It approaches many of the questions in the current debate on education.

results.title: Just the job
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Jenny Day and Soerabaia Pictures
results.brief_description: Designed as an aid for those who are about to leave school and try for a place in the work force. Outlines the kind of trade and post-trade courses available, as well as basic apprenticeship courses and development courses for various skills. Explains the need to find out as much as possible about a job, to ask questions, and talk to teachers.

results.title: My friends call me Tony
results.creator_credit: Beverly Shaffer, Kathleen Shannon, Yuki Yoshida and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The film is about a ten-year-old boy who can distinguish only light from shadow. Despite this difficulty, he leads a very active life. The film shows how Tony Rossi manages his life. Awards: Lausanne; Los Angeles.

results.title: My friend Angelmouse
results.creator_credit: Graham Ralph, Mark Mason, Jackie Edwards, BBC and Silver Fox
results.brief_description: Meet Angelmouse, a cheeky and mischievous heaven-sent hero and his many delightful friends in these ten fun-filled adventures. Voiced by David Jason, these charming tales are best suited for children aged 3-5 years. Episodes include: My friend Angelmouse; Lost Thingamajig; Windy weather day; Trumpet; Baby Ellie’s Presents; Angelcake; Copycat chick; Angelmouse’s day off; A Visitor for Angelmouse; Angelmouse’s reward.

results.title: Dad and Dave: on our selection
results.creator_credit: George Whaley, Anthony Buckley, Bruce Davey, AFFC, Anthony Buckley Productions and ICON
results.brief_description: Steele Rudd’s classic Dad and Dave stories represent what is both noble and comic in colonial society. The Rudd’s are a loud, unconventional farming family, ekeing out a living in the harsh conditions of the bush with little respect for authority. Stereotypical “fair dinkum Aussies”, Dad’s blustering and Ma’s stoicism hold the family together. This film features the talents of an all-star cast including Leo McKern, Dame Joan Sutherland, Geoffrey Rush, Ray Barrett, Nicholas Eadie, Noah Taylor and Barry Otto, with songs and music by Peter Best.

results.title: Mr Bump
results.creator_credit: Terry Ward, Trevor Bond and Animation Flicks Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mr Men”.
An animated film based on the “Mr. Men” books by Roger Hargreaves. “Mr Bump” is the story of a little man who continuously bumps into things and causes accidents. But one day he finds a job that perfectly suits his unfortunate habit.

results.title: D.W. Griffith: father of film
results.creator_credit: David Gill, Kevin Brownlow, Channel Four and Thames Television
results.brief_description: A three part survey of the life and work of D.W. Griffith. His formative years in the theatre and at Biograph were followed by his major successes between 1915-1921: “The Birth of a nation”, “Broken blossoms”, “Way down east” and “Orphans of the storm”. The subsequently influential “Intolerance” was a critical and commercial failure prefiguring the failure, in the twenties, of “America”, “Isn’t life wonderful” and “The Sorrows of Satan” and later, of his neglected sound films, “Abraham Lincoln” and “The Struggle”. Brownlow and Gill make extensive use of colour-tinted extracts from his films and interviews with Lillian Gish, Blanche Sweet, Karl Brown and others. Narrated by Lindsay Anderson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Gill, Kevin Brownlow, Channel Four and Thames Television
